etymologies: early 20th century; earliest use found in Journal of the Chemical Society. From pyr- + -an

definitions: Each of two unsaturated, heterocyclic compounds having the formula C₅ H₆ O, whose molecules have a six-membered ring consisting of five carbon atoms and one oxygen atom with two double bonds between carbon atoms; specifically γ-pyran. Also: a substituted derivative of such a compound; any compound containing a pyran ring.

notes.text: There are two possible isomeric forms of pyran, differing in the positions of the double bonds. Of these isomers, only one (more fully "γ-pyran"), CH₂CHCHCHCHO, has been prepared; it is a colourless, unstable oil.
